proposal_metadata.ancillary_data:
q: title: Will Trump lower tariffs on Canada by May 31?, description: This market will resolve to "Yes" if Donald Trump signs any federal legislation or performs any executive action that lowers, pauses, delays, or removes any tariffs on imports from Canada by May 31, 2025, 11:59 PM ET. Otherwise, this market will resolve to "No".

Actions that lower, pause, delay, or remove any tariffs on Canadian imports will qualify, including changes to the reciprocal tariff, or any other existing or new tariffs specifically targeting Canadian goods.

Only the removal of tariffs specifically targeting Canada will qualify. For example, the removal of the 10% general tariff on all imports into the U.S., or a tariff on specific Canadian provinces or entities, will not count toward this market's resolution.

Item-specific tariff exemptions, such as those outlined in the U.S. Customs and Border Protection notice dated April 11, 2025, which excluded 25 HTSUS codes covering electronics, will not qualify.

Any action officially enacted within the market's time frame will qualify, regardless of when the change goes into effect.

This market's primary resolution source will be official information from the Trump administration; however, a consensus of credible information from major news outlets or government statements will also be used.
proposal_metadata.resolution_conditions: res_data:p1: 0, p2: 1, p3: 0.5. Where p1 corresponds to No, p2 to Yes, p3 to unknown/50-50.
proposal_metadata.creator: 0x6A9D222616C90FcA5754cd1333cFD9b7fb6a4F74
updates: (1748542517, b'We\xe2\x80\x99re aware of the dispute on this market. If a clarification is to be issued, it will be at 3 PM ET. If no statement is issued at that time, then there will be no clarification by the Polymarket team. \n\nThe orderbook will be cleared at 3 PM ET regardless of whether a clarification is made.')

(1748545235, b'As it pertains to pauses, delays, or removals of tariffs, judicial or other actions not initiated by the Trump administration, which ban or block the listed tariff, will not alone qualify. However, if the Trump administration - including any executive branch agency such as U.S. Customs and Border Protection (CBP) - pauses, delays, removes or otherwise ceases enforcement of the listed tariff in compliance with a court order, this will qualify even if not publicly announced or formalized by legislation or an executive order.')

tokens.resolution_conditions: res_data:p1: 0, p2: 1, p3: 0.5. Where p1 corresponds to No, p2 to Yes, p3 to unknown/50-50.

journey.prompt:
You are an expert router for UMA's optimistic oracle system. Your task is to analyze the provided query and decide which AI solver is best suited to handle it.

Available solvers: perplexity, code_runner

Solver descriptions:
- perplexity: Uses the Perplexity AI search engine to find information online to answer general questions. Best for:
  * Historical data and events
  * General knowledge questions requiring context
  * Questions needing interpretation of complex information
  * Has knowledge cutoff and may not have very recent information

- code_runner: Executes code to fetch real-time data from specific APIs. Currently supports:
  * Binance API: Can fetch cryptocurrency prices at specific times/dates with timezone conversion
  * Sports Data IO: Can retrieve sports data from various leagues
  * Available Crypto Data Sources:
    - Binance: Provides cryptocurrency price data for Bitcoin, Ethereum, and other cryptocurrencies
  * Available Sports Data Sources:
    - Sports Data IO - MLB (baseball): MLB baseball scores, statistics, and game data
    - Sports Data IO - NBA (basketball): NBA basketball scores, statistics, and game data
    - Sports Data IO - NFL (football): NFL football scores, statistics, and game data
    - Sports Data IO - NHL (hockey): NHL hockey scores, statistics, and game data
    - Sports Data IO - CFB (college football): College Football (NCAA) scores, statistics, and game data
    - Sports Data IO - CBB (college basketball): College Basketball (NCAA) scores, statistics, and game data
  * Best for questions requiring precise, current data from these specific sources
  * Limited to only these data sources - cannot access other APIs or general information

USER PROMPT:
user:

ancillary_data:
q: title: Will Trump lower tariffs on Canada by May 31?, description: This market will resolve to "Yes" if Donald Trump signs any federal legislation or performs any executive action that lowers, pauses, delays, or removes any tariffs on imports from Canada by May 31, 2025, 11:59 PM ET. Otherwise, this market will resolve to "No".

Actions that lower, pause, delay, or remove any tariffs on Canadian imports will qualify, including changes to the reciprocal tariff, or any other existing or new tariffs specifically targeting Canadian goods.

Only the removal of tariffs specifically targeting Canada will qualify. For example, the removal of the 10% general tariff on all imports into the U.S., or a tariff on specific Canadian provinces or entities, will not count toward this market's resolution.

Item-specific tariff exemptions, such as those outlined in the U.S. Customs and Border Protection notice dated April 11, 2025, which excluded 25 HTSUS codes covering electronics, will not qualify.

Any action officially enacted within the market's time frame will qualify, regardless of when the change goes into effect.

This market's primary resolution source will be official information from the Trump administration; however, a consensus of credible information from major news outlets or government statements will also be used.

resolution_conditions:
res_data:p1: 0, p2: 1, p3: 0.5. Where p1 corresponds to No, p2 to Yes, p3 to unknown/50-50.

updates:
["(1748542517, b'We\\xe2\\x80\\x99re aware of the dispute on this market. If a clarification is to be issued, it will be at 3 PM ET. If no statement is issued at that time, then there will be no clarification by the Polymarket team. \\n\\nThe orderbook will be cleared at 3 PM ET regardless of whether a clarification is made.')", "(1748545235, b'As it pertains to pauses, delays, or removals of tariffs, judicial or other actions not initiated by the Trump administration, which ban or block the listed tariff, will not alone qualify. However, if the Trump administration - including any executive branch agency such as U.S. Customs and Border Protection (CBP) - pauses, delays, removes or otherwise ceases enforcement of the listed tariff in compliance with a court order, this will qualify even if not publicly announced or formalized by legislation or an executive order.')"]

Please analyze the prompt carefully, considering:
1. The complexity of the query
2. The type of information needed
3. Whether the question requires specialized knowledge or data access
4. Whether the question specifically involves cryptocurrency prices or sports data
5. Whether multiple approaches might be complementary

IMPORTANT: You SHOULD select MULTIPLE solvers when appropriate. For complementary approaches, multiple solvers can provide different perspectives on the same question.

Return your answer in a specific format:
```decision
{
  "solvers": ["solver_name1", "solver_name2"],
  "reason": "Brief explanation of why these solvers are best suited",
  "multi_solver_strategy": "Optional explanation of how these solvers complement each other"
}
```

Where:
- solvers: Array of solver names selected from the available solvers
- reason: A brief explanation of why you selected these solvers
- multi_solver_strategy: If multiple solvers are selected, explain how they complement each other

Guidelines for solver selection:
- Use code_runner when the question specifically asks for:
  * Current or historical cryptocurrency prices from Binance (e.g., "What was the price of BTC on March 30th at 12pm ET?")
  * Including: "What was the price of BTC on April 9th at noon ET?", "Was Ethereum higher or lower at the end of yesterday than at the start?"
  * Sports data results, scores or team performance from available sources (e.g., "Did the Blue Jays win against the Orioles on April 1st?")
  * Specifically for: baseball (e.g., "Did the Yankees win yesterday?"), basketball (e.g., "Who won the Lakers vs Warriors game?"), football (e.g., "Did the Eagles cover the spread against the Cowboys?"), hockey (e.g., "Did the Maple Leafs win yesterday?"), college football (e.g., "What was the score of the Alabama game last Saturday?"), college basketball (e.g., "What was Duke's score in their last game?")
  
- Use perplexity when the question requires:
  * General knowledge or context not limited to specific data points
  * Explanation or interpretation of events, rules, or concepts
  * Information beyond just crypto prices or MLB sports data
  
- Use both solvers when:
  * The question needs both factual data AND context/interpretation
  * Example: "Did BTC price increase after the news about XYZ on March 30th?" (code_runner for price data, perplexity for news context)
  * Example: "How did the Blue Jays perform compared to expectations in their April 1st game?" (code_runner for game data, perplexity for context about expectations)

Remember: code_runner is highly accurate for the supported data types but limited in scope. Perplexity has broader knowledge but may not have the most current information.

response.reason: The query involves understanding and interpreting potential future actions by a political figure regarding tariffs, which requires access to general knowledge, historical context, and the ability to interpret complex political and legal information. This is beyond the scope of the code_runner, which is limited to fetching specific data types like cryptocurrency prices and sports scores.

journey.full_response:
```decision
{
  "solvers": ["perplexity"],
  "reason": "The query involves understanding and interpreting potential future actions by a political figure regarding tariffs, which requires access to general knowledge, historical context, and the ability to interpret complex political and legal information. This is beyond the scope of the code_runner, which is limited to fetching specific data types like cryptocurrency prices and sports scores.",
  "multi_solver_strategy": ""
}
```

journey.response:
<think>
Okay, let's tackle this query. The user wants to know if Trump will lower tariffs on Canada by May 31, 2025. The resolution conditions are specific: any federal legislation or executive action that lowers, pauses, delays, or removes tariffs on Canadian imports by the deadline. The answer has to be a yes or no, with p2 being yes and p1 no. 

First, I need to check the search results provided. Let's go through them one by one. 

Search result [1] mentions that Trump's administration has been involved in a trade war with China, including tariff increases and a subsequent deal lowering them to 10% for U.S. goods and 30% for Chinese goods. But this is about China, not Canada. However, it does show a pattern of Trump using tariffs and then negotiating reductions.

Result [2] is a countdown timer to the end of Trump's presidency in 2029, not directly relevant here.

Result [3] discusses Trump's early actions in his second term, including many executive orders and legal challenges. It mentions the Laken Riley Act and immigration policies but not tariffs on Canada.

Result [4] talks about the constitutional powers of the president to issue executive orders, which is relevant because the query includes executive actions. It notes that some of Trump's orders have been blocked by courts, which might be important if there's a court order involved.

Result [5] explains how a bill becomes law, which is useful for understanding if any legislation was passed regarding tariffs. But the user's query includes both legislation and executive actions.

Result [6] is about Representative Meeks introducing resolutions to terminate Trump's authority to impose tariffs on Canada and Mexico. However, resolutions from Congress don't automatically become law unless passed by both houses and signed by the president. The article is from March 2025, so if Trump signed such a resolution, that would count. But the result says Meeks "intends" to introduce them, not that they were passed.

Result [7] is a thesis on state legislative opposition, not directly relevant to federal actions on tariffs.

Result [8] covers Trump's first presidency, which is historical and not directly relevant to 2025 actions.

Result [9] from Kiplinger dated June 2, 2025, states that on May 12, the U.S. and China agreed to a 90-day tariff reduction. It also mentions that as of May 12, U.S.-Canada trade relations shifted toward negotiation after months of tariffs. Additionally, there's a mention of a meeting in early May where Trump and Canadian PM Carney agreed to a broad trade platform and negotiation process. This could indicate a reduction or pause in tariffs as part of negotiations. However, the exact nature of the agreement isn't clear. The article also notes that Canada had imposed tariffs on U.S. goods, and both sides were considering expanding them if talks stalled. But after the May meeting, they were focused on negotiation.

Result [10] from Wikipedia details the 2025 trade war with Canada and Mexico. It mentions that on March 6, Trump delayed tariffs on USMCA-compliant goods, which accounted for 50% of imports from Mexico and 38% from Canada. The exemption was expected to end on April 2 but was continued indefinitely. Later, the U.S. imposed universal tariffs on steel, aluminum, and automotive imports, including from Canada. However, on April 3, Trump imposed a 25% tariff on all imported cars, including from Canada. But on March 6, there was a delay for USMCA-compliant goods until April 2. The key point here is whether any of these actions involved lowering, pausing, delaying, or removing tariffs on Canada by May 31.

Result [11] from White & Case on February 2, 2025, states that Trump imposed 25% tariffs on Canada and Mexico, effective February 4, with exemptions for goods in transit before February 1. It also mentions that the tariffs could be raised further if retaliation occurs. However, this is from early February, before the May deadline.

Result [12] from Investopedia on February 3, 2025, says that Trump delayed tariffs on Canada for 30 days after negotiations. This would be a pause, which qualifies under the resolution conditions. The delay was until March 4, 2025. But the user's query is about actions by May 31, so this delay in February would count as a pause, but does it fall within the timeframe? The market's deadline is May 31, so yes. However, the update in the query mentions that judicial actions not initiated by the Trump administration don't count, but if the administration complies with a court order, it does. However, in this case, the delay was a direct action by Trump, not a court order.

Result [13] from Senator Klobuchar's site on April 2, 2025, states that the Senate passed a bill to end Trump's tariffs on Canadian imports. If Trump signed this bill into law, that would qualify. The article says the bill was passed by the Senate, but it doesn't mention Trump signing it. The bill would need to pass the House and be signed by the president. The result doesn't specify if it became law, so we can't assume it was enacted unless there's evidence. The date is April 2, within the timeframe, but without confirmation of enactment, this might not count.

Result [14] from CBS News on February 3, 2025, confirms the 30-day pause on Canadian tariffs, which aligns with result [12]. This is a direct action by Trump, so it qualifies as a pause.

Result [15] from Politico on February 3, 2025, also confirms the 30-day delay on tariffs for Canada and Mexico. This is another source confirming the pause.

Result [16] from Supply Chain Dive on February 3, 2025, reiterates the 30-day pause agreed between the U.S. and Canada. This is a valid pause within the timeframe.

Result [17] from Wikipedia's tariffs in the second Trump administration mentions that on March 6, Trump delayed tariffs on USMCA-compliant goods until April 2. Then on April 3, he imposed new tariffs on cars, including from Canada. However, the delay until April 2 is a pause, which would count if it happened before May 31. The April 3 action is an increase, not a reduction.

Result [18] from Supply Chain Dive on March 6, 2025, states that Trump extended the tariff pause on USMCA-compliant goods until April 2. This is another pause within the timeframe.

Additionally, the updates in the query clarify that if the Trump administration ceases enforcement due to a court order, it counts even without a public announcement. However, in the cases above, the pauses were initiated by Trump, not court-ordered. 

Putting this together: 

- On February 3, 2025, Trump paused tariffs on Canada for 30 days ([12], [14], [15], [16]). This is a "pause" as per the resolution conditions.
- On March 6, 2025, Trump extended the pause on USMCA-compliant goods until April 2 ([17], [18]). Another pause.
- The Senate passed a bill on April 2 to end tariffs, but without confirmation of Trump's signature, this might not count ([13]).
- The Kiplinger article from June 2 ([9]) mentions that as of May 12, the U.S. and Canada were in negotiations, but doesn't specify a tariff reduction. However, it does mention a meeting in early May leading to a negotiation process. If this resulted in a formal agreement to lower tariffs, that would count. The article states, "Following a meeting in early May, Trump and Carney seem to have agreed to a broad trade platform and negotiation process." But it's unclear if this included any tariff reductions or pauses. The article also mentions that the U.S. and China agreed to a 90-day tariff reduction on May 12, but that's separate from Canada.

The key actions are the pauses in February and March. Both fall before May 31. The resolution conditions state that any action enacted within the timeframe counts, regardless of when it takes effect. Therefore, the pauses in February and March qualify as "pauses" or "delays" of tariffs on Canada. 

The query's updates mention that judicial actions not initiated by Trump don't count, but the pauses here were executive actions, so they qualify. Additionally, the ancillary data specifies that item-specific exemptions (like the 25 HTSUS codes) don't count, but the pauses here are broader, affecting all tariffs under the specified orders.

Therefore, the answer should be "Yes" (p2) because Trump did pause tariffs on Canada multiple times before May 31, 2025.
</think>

recommendation: p2

Okay, let's tackle this query step by step. The user is asking whether Trump will lower tariffs on Canada by May 31, 2025, based on specific resolution conditions. The ancillary data defines that the market resolves to "Yes" if Trump takes any federal legislation or executive action to lower, pause, delay, or remove tariffs on Canadian imports by that date. The resolution conditions are p1: No, p2: Yes, p3: 50-50. 

First, I need to review the provided search results to find any actions taken by the Trump administration regarding Canadian tariffs up to May 31, 2025. The current date given is June 4, 2025, so the cutoff is just a few days prior. 

Looking at the sources, there's a lot about tariffs imposed in early 2025. For example, source [10] mentions Trump imposing 25% tariffs on Canada and Mexico starting February 1, 2025. Then, source [14] says on February 3, 2025, the U.S. paused these tariffs for 30 days until March 4. Source [15] from March 6, 2025, states that Trump extended the pause on USMCA-compliant goods until April 2. Source [17] from April 2 clarifies that USMCA-compliant goods remain exempt, but non-compliant ones face 25% tariffs. 

In source [13], dated May 29, 2025, it mentions a federal appeals court staying rulings against Trump's tariffs, leaving them in place. Also, on April 9, the Trump administration paused most new tariffs for 90 days, but the 25% on some Canadian goods remained. However, this 90-day pause would expire on July 8, which is after May 31, so it doesn't affect the cutoff. 

The key point is whether any tariff reductions, pauses, delays, or removals specifically targeting Canada occurred by May 31. The pauses in February and March were temporary and applied to USMCA-compliant goods. The April 2 announcement continued exemptions for USMCA-compliant items but kept tariffs on others. There's no mention of any further actions by Trump to lower or remove these tariffs before May 31. The court rulings in May didn't result in administrative actions that changed the tariffs; instead, the appeals court kept them in place. 

The user's update mentions that judicial actions not initiated by Trump don't count unless the administration complies. The May court decision didn't lead to any administrative changes by Trump, so it doesn't qualify. Therefore, within the timeframe, Trump's actions were pauses and exemptions for USMCA goods, but these were already in place before May. No new actions after April 2 up to May 31 are noted in the sources. Hence, the answer should be "No," corresponding to p1.
</think>

q: title: Will Trump lower tariffs on Canada by May 31?, description: This market will resolve to "Yes" if Donald Trump signs any federal legislation or performs any executive action that lowers, pauses, delays, or removes any tariffs on imports from Canada by May 31, 2025, 11:59 PM ET. Otherwise, this market will resolve to "No".

Actions that lower, pause, delay, or remove any tariffs on Canadian imports will qualify, including changes to the reciprocal tariff, or any other existing or new tariffs specifically targeting Canadian goods.

Only the removal of tariffs specifically targeting Canada will qualify. For example, the removal of the 10% general tariff on all imports into the U.S., or a tariff on specific Canadian provinces or entities, will not count toward this market's resolution.

Item-specific tariff exemptions, such as those outlined in the U.S. Customs and Border Protection notice dated April 11, 2025, which excluded 25 HTSUS codes covering electronics, will not qualify.

Any action officially enacted within the market's time frame will qualify, regardless of when the change goes into effect.

This market's primary resolution source will be official information from the Trump administration; however, a consensus of credible information from major news outlets or government statements will also be used.

resolution_conditions:

However, if the Trump administration - including any executive branch agency such as U.S. Customs and Border Protection (CBP) - pauses, delays, removes or otherwise ceases enforcement of the listed tariff in compliance with a court order, this will qualify even if not publicly announced or formalized by legislation or an executive order.')"]
